original_content:
We all know how a conventional internal combustion engine works, with a piston and a crankshaft. But thats by no means the only way to make an engine, and one of the slightly more unusual alternatives comes to us courtesy of a vintage Shell Film Unit film, The Free Piston Engine, which weve placed below the break. Its a beautiful period piece of mid-century animation and jazz, but its also  an introduction to these fascinating machines.
Were introduced to the traditional two-stroke diesel engine as thermally efficient but not smooth-running, and then the gas turbine as smooth but much more inefficient. The free piston engine, a design with opposed pistons working against compressed air springs and combining both compression and firing strokes in a single axis, doesnt turn anything  in itself, but instead works as a continuous supplier of high pressure combustion gasses. The clever part of this arrangement is that these gasses can then turn the power turbine from a gas turbine engine, achieving a smooth engine without compromising efficiency.
This sounds like a promising design for an engine, and were introduced to a rosy picture of railway locomotives, ships, factories, and power stations all driven by free piston engines. Why then, here in 2024 do we not see them everywhere? A quick Google search reveals an inordinately high number of scientific review papers about them but not so many real-world examples. In that theyre not alone, for alternative engine designs are one of those technologies for which if we had a dollar for every one wed seen that didnt make it, as the saying goes, wed be rich.
It seems that the problem with these engines is that they dont offer the control over their timing that were used to from more conventional designs, and thus the speed of their operation also cant be controlled. The British firm Libertine claim to have solved this with their line of linear electrical generators, but perhaps understandably for commercial reasons they are a little coy about the details. Their focus is on free piston engines as power sources for hybrid electric vehicles, something which due to their small size they seem ideally suited for.
Perhaps the free piston engine has faced its biggest problem not in the matter of technology but in inertia. Theres an old saying in the computer industry: Nobody ever got fired for buying IBM, meaning that the conventional conservative choice always wins, and its fair to guess that the same applies anywhere a large engine has been needed. A conventional diesel engine may be a complex device with many moving parts, but its a well-understood machine that whoever wields the cheque book feels comfortable with. Thats a huge obstacle for any new technology to climb. Meanwhile though it offers obvious benefits in terms of efficiency, at the moment its time could have come due to environmental concerns, any internal combustion engine has fallen out of fashion. Its possible that it could find a life as an engine running on an alternative fuel such as hydrogen or ammonia, but were not so sure. If new free piston engines do take off though, well be more pleased than anyone to eat our words.
title: 自作可能なエンジン：自由ピストンエンジンの仕組み
body: 伝統的な内燃機関やガスタービンに代わるエンジンの1つは、自由ピストンエンジンです。2ストロークディーゼルエンジンやガスタービンと比較し、効率的で滑らか。タイミングの制御が課題で、自由ピストンエンジンは革新的な技術にも関わらず、普及には課題が残る。
